security: Revealing that checks of agency indices did not turn up a John S Newman, along with the mention of Cuban CI officers' 'parallel contacts' with CIA officials expected to be in attendance, could reveal sources and methods used to gather information. Specifically, “CHECKS OF AGENCY INDICES DID NOT TURN UP A JOHN S NEWMAN AS A CURRENT STAFFER…CUBAN CI OFFICERS' 'PARALLEL CONTACTS' WITH CIA OFFICIALS EXPECTED TO BE IN ATTENDANCE.” This could compromise intelligence gathering efforts and relationships.
summary: A cable discusses a Rio meeting involving Cuban CI officers and alleged CIA officers, requesting further information on the seminar, attendees, and the Cuban hand in organizing the event. It also references Fabian Escalante's belief that elements of the CIA operational arm, in combination with the Mafia, were responsible for the assassination of President Kennedy.
summary_one_paragraph: This cable, dated August 12, 1995, from LIMIT CIC/LA to Sao Paulo, Brasilia, and Havana, addresses a Rio meeting between Cuban Counterintelligence (CI) officers and alleged CIA officers. The cable requests additional details about the seminar organized by Jose Lisboa da Gama Malcher, particularly regarding the agenda, attendees, and any planned attendance by individuals like Agee. The dispatch notes that a check of Agency indices did not reveal a current staffer named John S. Newman. Furthermore, it references Fabian Escalante’s belief that elements within the CIA, combined with the Mafia, were responsible for President Kennedy's assassination and also discusses Escalante’s background, including his former role as the Chief of Counterintelligence for the US during the Missile Crisis.
title: RIO MEETING OF CUBAN CI OFFICERS AND ALLEGED CIA OFFICERS
conspiracy: The document includes information regarding Fabian Escalante's belief that 'some elements of the CIA operational arm' in combination with the Mafia were responsible for the assassination of President Kennedy. Escalante made it clear that he did not believe the CIA acted on its own.
